data.title: Godot should look for export template at system-wide level too
data.body: that's all :)

data.title: Non-uniform scaling with capsule/circle
data.body:
In the documentations, it is said that we mustn't scale capsule/circle shaped CollisionShape2D.

I guess it is common knowledge that with platformers, when the collision shape has corners, it causes problems in various places. So using a capsule or circle is better.

Now, the problem is of course, not everything can be described by a capsule or circle scaled uniformly.
I for instance have a ~50x100 character, which can crouch, among other things (combined with #1024 this is really troublesome).

I'm hoping that this "restriction" (or rather, bug) will be gone in the future (Unity doesn't have such a weird restriction).
Is it in the plans?

data.title: Absolute coordinates for CollisionShape2D
data.body:
Let me explain what I'm trying to achieve first.

I have a 2D sprite with different animations (standing, idle, etc). I'm trying to get the collision boxes right for each animation. The height of the crouching sprite is at bit less than the standing height, so the collision boxes (using a rectange for now) should be adjuested.

Now, the important thing is, for both standing and crouching animations, the bottom part of the collision rectange should have the same y coordinates (otherwise, crouching could cause a fall down and the character would be "buried" into the ground).

How can I do that with CollisionShape2D (and RectangleShape2D)?

When I try to change the height of the collision rectange, it changes both ways in the y-axis. Say, I just finished with the standing animation, and now I'm trying to make the collision rect smaller for crouching animation (without altering the position). Surely, the top part of the collision rect gets lower but at the same time, the bottom part of the collision rectangle gets up!

I know about the pixel snap, but unfortunately, due to the way the way the feet are drawn, collision boxes are not exactly pixel-perfect aligned with the sprites (the sprites look a bit realistic with depth, they're not exactly Mario :)). Which is a problem, because even a single pixel is problem.

Is there an easy/managable way of ensuring the bottom part of the collision box remains at the same y-coordinate?
If there was a way of entering the absolute coordinates of the four edges of the rectange in the editor, that would be super nice.

data.title: 3d version of Raycast lacks exclusion list
data.body:
A while ago, exclusion lists were added to Raycast2d to allow casting rays from inside of interesing objects (namely, player's body). 

However, this was never added to 3d raycast, so casting rays from an embodied camera is still problematic.

data.title: get_as_text() does not concatenate the last line
data.body:
Hi,

As discovered by Surt into the forum : http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=1220

**get_as_text()** ignores the last line of the file, unless a carriage return is added at the end.

It appears to work this way because the eof is already reached into the **FileAccess::get_line()** function on which relies **_File::get_as_text()**.

data.title: Sound sample not audible in AnimationPlayer editor
data.body:
Concerns: 1.0 stable

I have keyframed play on a SpatialSamplePlayer in my Animation.
It works when the game is running, but during editing of the animation, when I press play there is no sound. This makes timing a bit difficult.

data.title: iOS simulator build is broken
data.body:
To reproduce the issue clone the repo and run SCons to build the simulator executable

```
scons p=isim bin/godot.isim.tools
```

A workaround is to run SCons to build the arm executable first

```
scons p=iphone bin/godot.iphone.debug
```

...then run the SCons again to build the simulator executable

data.title: minor UI: prevent resetting pinned animation editor
data.body: If you have a pinned animation editor, and you click somewhere in the timeline where you want to insert a keyframe, then click on another animation editor (to keyframe playing of another animation, for instance), it will reset back to the 0 position. It should only do this if there is no animation editor currently pinned.

data.title: can delete text in readonly TextEdit
data.body: If you select the text (shift + home/end/arrow keys) you can delete the selected text from a read only TextEdit control.  It doesn't appear to be accepting any other keystrokes.  Backspace and delete do nothing (as expected) unless there is selected text.

data.title: remove EmptyControl
data.body: EmptyControl has been deprecated and should have been removed prior to 1.0.

data.title: minor UI glitch: sampleplayer doesn't show samples after loading library
data.body: if you have a sampleplayer node (or maybe sampleplayer2d, I forget), and you load a library into the samples, the play parameter stays at an integer spinbox. it should be updated to the menu list of samples in the library. currently you have to click away to another node, and back for this to show up correctly. again, this is minor, but there's a UI push for 1.1 so I'm submitting these things I find.

data.title: Android SensorManager registerListener delay parameter NORMAL to GAME
data.body:
Android SensorManager registerListener delay parameter is set SENSOR_DELAY_NORMAL.
I hope it change to SENSOR_DELAY_GAME.

data.title: fixed bugs in polygon_path_finder for finding nearest points
data.body: fixed bugs in polygon_path_finder for finding nearest points

data.title: 3D platformer code is overly complex
data.body:
Can't the 3D platformer be simplified? (or a simpler one can't be added?)

The corresponding Unity tutorial project is much simpler (and works a lot better and smoother):

http://unity3d.com/learn/tutorials/projects/stealth/player-movement
vs
https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/blob/master/demos/3d/platformer/player.gd

http://unity3d.com/learn/tutorials/projects/stealth/camera-movement
vs
https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/blob/master/demos/3d/platformer/follow_camera.gd

I'm also trying to understand: with godot, many stuff have to be done manually, but the corresponding Unity code feels like a breeze.

Is the 3d platformer demo a badly written godot code (in which case I was hoping a simpler re-write), or that's just the way things get done in godot?

I know, it's not exactly apples-to-apples comparison, but I'm referring to the things aside from jump/shots. In comparison, the way facing, movement or camera is handled, manual physics, manually checking if there is stuff there or not etc. is bloated code with godot (and Unity version has a very smooth transitions with quaternion lerps).

Camera code is also seriously complicate (and buggy); Unity camera code is quite simple and smooth.

Please please tell me that that is just a non-idiomatic, badly written godot code :)

Oh, and I think godo would benefit from a similar demo (you know, without jumps and bullets, just to demonstrate basic 3D stuff, maybe with light baking)

data.title: [suggestion] about 2d tilemap filtering artifacts
data.body:
Hi,

Into the tilemap tutorial, it is said that when using a single texture for all the tiles, it will most likely result in filtering artifacts that can't be avoided, unless disabling filtering or using workarounds.

In my previous attempt at writing an opengl tilemap game engine, I solved this problem by adding an inset of about 0.5 pixel to the UV coords of the tiles.
This inset was small ennough to be unoticiable, and allowed the use of filtered texture without artifacts.

I haven't looked deep ennough into Godot source code, so I duno if it is possible or not, and I have not found a conversation about it into the forum, so duno if you tried that already. So, just in case, you have this suggestion ...

data.title: Project Settings / General / locale / fallback seems ineffective
data.body:
Hi,
I'm still on stable 1.0 version, win64.

Unless I did not understand how to use it, or what it is actually supposed to do, the **locale/fallback** option into the **project settings** seems not to work.

I explain : In case I don't provide a translation for a locale, I want the translator to use the "en" locale instead. So I put "en" into the **fallback** field.

However, it seems not to work. If I run command line for lang that I donot support, Instead of displaying the english translation, it keeps displaying the key ID.

Bug or misunderstanding ?

Edit : indeed the workaround would be to use english translations as keys .....

Edit 2 : oh, and I was using it to translate a Label in which I put a string key name "LIKE_THIS_ID"

data.title: Renaming Input Actions
data.body: This is a quite minor issue, but it could be useful to be able to rename the Input Actions in the GUI. With the current GUI you have to remove the action, create a new one with the new name, and assign all the keys again. As a workaround it is probably quicker and easier to rename them in the engine.cfg file.

data.title: [request] emit an error if a setget function is not found
data.body:
Hi,
I'm on STABLE 1.0, win64.

```
var A = 0 setget A_changed
```

If the A_changed() setter func is not found, the debugger does not complains about it.
I've spent half an hour figuring out I misspelled a setter func name ...

It would be cool if missing setter/getter func were detected by the debugger.

data.title: Option control renders item list at the wrong location
data.body:
Hey all, been playing around with Godot for a bit now and ran into a problem regarding the option control. When I use a Node2D as the main scene node, the option item list shows up at the top left of the option control. When using a Control as the main scene node, the option item list shows at the top left the game window. (See screenshots).

The following link is a zip file containing my test project: https://app.box.com/s/sc0bobjgufiz5ok1cey6

Excuse me if the following explanation may be a bit sluggish, I am new to github, and would just like to see this bug solved.

What I've basically done is setup a hierachy in my main scene such as this:
Node2D -> "main"
- WindowDialog -> "dialog_mainmenu"
- Button -> "button_startgame"
- Button -> "button_quitgame"
- Optionbox -> "option_difficulty"

After that, I've added code, in the _ready() function of the Node2D -> "main" script, in order to add the items to the option control.

![screen shot 2014-12-19 at 19 19 56](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10252874/5515013/fdd37422-8856-11e4-8085-eb7dbd457711.png)
![screen shot 2014-12-20 at 06 46 01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10252874/5515014/fe2c4246-8856-11e4-836b-0563e6888c09.png)

While trying to figure out where the problem lies in C++, I also noticed that with the clean source code, the Tooltip positions incorrectly as well.

![screen shot 2014-12-20 at 16 24 26](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10252874/5515308/c1a39df2-8864-11e4-9497-0158c8759021.png)

data.title: _ready called twice when created 	dynamically
New scene instance type - Background.
data.body:
In a basic sense, you would have a scene instance with an option that sets it as a background for the current gameplay scene. It would work as follows...

---
- Anything in the background type will be drawn after everything else, meaning that objects and textures in it will only appear whenever there is empty space showing through in the main scene (where the skybox would otherwise be).
- Have an option to allow the background scene's sky texture and/or environmental settings override that of the main scene
- Objects in general in the background scene would not be able to collide with objects in the main scene, however, you can move objects in the background scene (such as basing their movement on an object in the main scene).
## Uses
1. Using it as a true 3D perspective background in a 2D game
2. Using it as a skybox with animation and dynamic properties
3. Using it as a 3D background with 3D games
4. Dynamic muiti-layered background effects using more than one background scene

Please respond if you think this or something similar would be a good idea to add to Godot

Thanks.

data.title: Cross Compilation for Windows from Linux fails
data.body:
## Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit

Building a linux copy works as shown below.

```
~/$ sudo apt-get install scons pkg-config libx11-dev libxcursor-dev build-essential libasound2-dev libfreetype6-dev libgl1-mesa-dev libglu-dev libssl-dev
~$ git clone https://github.com/okamstudio/godot.git
~$ cd godot/
~/godot$ scons platform=x11
```

Produces a working copy of Godot usable in the Linux environment.
## Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit cross compile

Here is the attempt to produce a Windows cross compiled version using Mingw on the above Ubuntu environment.  I've added the MingW 32 and 64-bit packages.

```
~/$ sudo apt-get install mingw32 mingw-w64
~$ cd godot/
~/godot$ scons platform=windows tools=no
```

Eventually we get an error from RtAudio complaining about a missing dsound.h from the DirectX SDK. 

```
i586-mingw32msvc-ranlib drivers/libdrivers1.windows.tools.32.a
i586-mingw32msvc-g++ -o drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.windows.tools.32.o -c -g -Wall -DDEBUG_ENABLED -DDEBUG_MEMORY_ENABLED -DFREETYPE_ENABLED -DWINDOWS_ENABLED -mwindows -DGLES2_ENABLED -DGLES1_ENABLED -DGLEW_ENABLED -DDEBUG_MEMORY_ALLOC -DSCI_NAMESPACE -DRTAUDIO_ENABLED -march=i686 -DMINGW_ENABLED -DMUSEPACK_ENABLED -DOPENSSL_ENABLED -DSQUISH_ENABLED -DVORBIS_ENABLED -DPNG_ENABLED -DDDS_ENABLED -DPVR_ENABLED -DJPG_ENABLED -DWEBP_ENABLED -DSPEEX_ENABLED -DTOOLS_ENABLED -DGDSCRIPT_ENABLED -DMINIZIP_ENABLED -DXML_ENABLED -DOPENSSL_NO_ASM -DOPENSSL_THREADS -DL_ENDIAN -Icore -Icore/math -Itools -Idrivers -I. -Iplatform/windows -Itools/freetype -Itools/freetype/freetype/include -Idrivers/builtin_openssl2 -Idrivers/builtin_zlib/zlib -Idrivers/rtaudio/vorbis -Idrivers/builtin_openssl2/crypto -Idrivers/builtin_openssl2/openssl -Idrivers/builtin_openssl2/crypto/evp -Idrivers/builtin_openssl2/crypto/asn1 -Idrivers/builtin_openssl2/crypto/modes drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp:5124:20: error: dsound.h: No such file or directory
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp: In member function 'virtual unsigned int RtApiDs::getDeviceCount()':
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp:5232: error: 'LPDSENUMCALLBACK' was not declared in this scope
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp:5232: error: 'DirectSoundEnumerate' was not declared in this scope
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp:5241: error: expected `)' before 'deviceQueryCallback'
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp:5241: error: 'DirectSoundCaptureEnumerate' was not declared in this scope
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp: In member function 'virtual RtAudio::DeviceInfo RtApiDs::getDeviceInfo(unsigned int)':
drivers/rtaudio/RtAudio.cpp:5284: error: 'LPDIRECTSOUND' was not declared in this scope
```

This problem used to be related to the missing support for dsound.h in MingW prior to 2010 but it has been added in recent years.

```
~/godot/drivers/rtaudio$ locate dsound.h
/usr/i686-w64-mingw32/include/dsound.h
/usr/share/mingw-w64/include/dsound.h
/usr/x86_64-w64-mingw32/include/dsound.h
```

As a Scons neophyte, I'm assuming I'm missing a compiler switch pointing to the MingW include and libraries path but have no idea where to start on adding that support.

Please fix, very annoying ;)
- Place cursor, hold shift, click somewhere else: Should select all text between. Doesnt work properly. Often forgets starting point. Behaves strangely when text is already selected. Should add/subtract from that selection, instad starts a new one.
- Holding control: Jumping or selecting (in combination with shift) whole words. Doesn't always work.

Thanks!

data.title: PulseAudio backend
data.body: This is a simple PulseAudio backend using PA's simple API based on the ALSA backend. It is built when the PA development libraries are installed (found by pkg-config). The patch also fixes the audio driver selection on X11.

data.title: [UI Bug] Z axis for editor windows not working properly
data.body:
Open editor, then open exporter. Next press "x" on editor window to close it, and there will appear "please confirm" on the top, but whe you try to click in it you click inside "export"... (and when click is inside "please confirm" that config box is still on the top after click)

tested on OS X Yosemite 10.10 on current HEAD

data.title: Pr-tween-fix
data.body:
1.Change interpolate_callback:p_times_in_sec argument before p_callback argument(more readable)
2.NodePath replace to instance_ID(can control object doe's not in scene tree)
3.Change interpolate types from Node to Object, can control more types(etc script class object)
4.Add pending_update counter, avoid insert/remove interpolates-list while traversal it

data.title: No textures/no lighting in 3D demos
data.body:
Edit: Apparently Fedora by default installs the 32bit version of the libtxc_dxtn and not the 64bit. Forcing the architecture fixed it.

On a fresh build of Godot on Fedora 21x64 with a Intel 4400. I am having issues with 3D demos - namely both the 3D Platformer and Kinematic Character 3D demos. 

Both lighting and textures look like they're having issues displaying (as you can see in the attached images).

The only errors in the console are:

ERROR: add_node:Condition ' p_type == NODE_OUTPUT ' is true.
At: scene/animation/animation_tree_player.cpp:817.

When looking at glxinfo I get the following:

 GL_ARB_ES2_compatibility, GL_ARB_ES3_compatibility, GL_ARB_base_instance, 
    GL_OES_EGL_image, GL_OES_read_format, GL_S3_s3tc
    GL_ARB_ES2_compatibility, GL_ARB_ES3_compatibility, 
    GL_OES_read_format, GL_S3_s3tc, GL_SGIS_generate_mipmap, 

libtcx_dxtn is installed.

![screenshot from 2014-12-18 20 54 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2192159/5500034/fd5f8882-86f8-11e4-8386-76cc4a760c2b.png)
![screenshot from 2014-12-18 20 20 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2192159/5500033/fd5a96b0-86f8-11e4-8f28-a01833d65dcb.png)
